newsitem.title: SPAIN: Centennial Airlines expands scheduled services.
newsitem.headline: Centennial Airlines expands scheduled services.

text.p: Spanish charter carrier Centennial Airlines SA is increasing its scheduled flights to London and planning several new regular services between Britain and Spain, commercial director Ian McIntosh said on Tuesday.

Centennial has been flying between Gatwick and Palma de Mallorca three times a week since 1994 but from September 1 has increased this to five, partly as a result of Iberia suspending its Palma-Gatwick service this month.
"We'd planned to do it anyway from April next year, but we decided to bring it forward," McIntosh said, adding that passenger load factors on the route had been at least 65 or 70 percent since June.

"We're looking at other (scheduled) routes to and from the U.K. such as Mahon, Ibiza, Alicante and Malaga from Gatwick and Manchester but it won't be until next summer or probably later," he told Reuters.

The airline, whose biggest shareholder is managing director Tomas Cano, has a fleet of five leased McDonnell Douglas MD-83s and is considering changing these for Airbus Industrie A320s when the leases expire.
It makes annual revenues of around 12.5 billion pesetas ($99.5 million). --Air Cargo Newsroom Tel+44 171 542 8982 Fax +44 171 542 5017 ($ = 125.6 Spanish Pesetas)
